awd_abstract_narration:
Stem cell research has been marked by scientific, ethical, and juridical concerns for nearly two decades. Additionally, stem cell therapy has wide-ranging implications for medical practice and for the future of bioscience, but important cultural differences in clinics and labs remain under-analyzed. This project focuses on the rise of stem cell research and epistemic cultures in three different labs that translate stem cell research into frontier science and stem cell therapies as they shift towards a market-oriented political culture of commercialization. The three labs to be investigated differ in terms of their transnational funding and networks, their standards for evidence-controlled experiments, their verification by the larger scientific community, and their level of commercialization. Instead of analyzing stem cell research through the lens of the nation-state, this project focuses on cultural differences of stem cell science within a nation. It thus investigates a broad range of settings that make knowledge production and circulation possible in stem cell research. 

This project investigates the mechanics of knowledge production in three laboratories in the context of the shift towards market-oriented political culture of science. It has two main objectives: (1) Investigation of differences in the epistemic cultures of stem cell research at the three laboratories by exploring differences in the deployment of literary, social, and material technologies in the production of scientific knowledge. It explores whether and how differences in the mechanics of knowledge production explain the differing epistemological and social responses towards the epistemic things produced at these three laboratories. (2) Investigation of the impact of the shifting market-oriented political culture of science on the three stem cell laboratories. The project, thus, explores: (a) how political culture has impacted the practices of the three laboratories, and (b) whether and how the national and international networks of the laboratories have led to differential impact on the credibility of the scientific practices at those laboratories despite their being located within the same regulatory regime.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The project shows how political and epistemic cultures of stem cell science in India have been differentially impacted because of national and international location. Stem cell research and therapy in India had started with the objective of making India "a global hub for stem cell research." However, proliferation of stem cell therapy clinics and resulting international criticisms made stem cell research and therapy in India a site of geopolitical friction, which resulted in continual changes in national policy and impacted epistemic cultures of stem cell labs/clinics. Nevertheless, as the project highlights through a study of three Indian stem cell research and therapy labs/clinics, the impact of location within a nation and internationally has been differential and was navigated differently, resulting in different technoscientific outcomes. The project found that ownership-status (public, private, or not-for-profit) did not matter much but the status of the clinic/lab within the national and international scientific community and among the policy makers played a significant role. Technoscientific practices at the government-owned hospital utilized the inescapable contingency in the translation between governmental rationality and the practice of government (that defines any national policy) and the reputation of the lead scientist to conduct cutting-edge cardiac related stem cell research and therapy. The not-for-profit clinic, on the other hand, used its organization as a boundary infrastructure, which had also resulted in several international collaborations, to further its eyecare related stem cell research and therapy and its findings continued to be well-received nationally and internationally. Moreover, both, the not-for-profit and the government-owned lab/clinic, navigated the international concerns by blaming clinics such as the private-owned one as the source of the problem. The private clinic, which was often criticized, internationally and nationally, for "selling a miracle," navigated the concerns by presenting its research and therapy not as outside science, but as the outside of the science - the frontier. This project, thus, shows how technoscience is practiced in the context of geopolitical frictions and how these frictions impact political and epistemic cultures of science(s) within a nation; the impact, nevertheless, is not same for all labs within the nation.


Last Modified: 06/29/2024
Modified by: Amit Prasad
